forecast.rationale: My forecast is based on the interplay between the strong, persistent long-term warming trend and short-term natural variability, primarily the El Niño-Southern Oscillation (ENSO) cycle. The background trend of anthropogenic climate change makes any given month a plausible candidate for a new record. However, the record-breaking months of 2023 and early 2024 were amplified by a strong El Niño event. By May 2025, climate models overwhelmingly indicate that this El Niño has ended, with the climate system being in either an ENSO-neutral or a La Niña state. La Niña has a temporary global cooling effect. Therefore, for May 2025 to be the hottest on record, the underlying warming trend would have to be strong enough to overcome the absence of the El Niño 'boost' and surpass a previous record that likely had it. While possible, this makes a new record less likely than not. The research assistant's report provided no new information, so this forecast relies on established climate science principles.
